moves.1. e4 e5 2. Bc4 b6: An interesting reply to the Bishop's Opening. Elzie apparently intends to fianchetto the QB and pressure Colvin's KP.
moves.3. Nc3 Bb7 4. f4: Almost a delayed King's Gambit. Clearly it catches Elzie off guard, because he plays an incredibly poor move in response.
moves.4... f6: Chess is 2/3 psychology. If you can spring a variant on your opponent that he's unprepared for, you can often induce a mistake... like this blunder, for instance.
moves.5. fxe5: Colvin exchanges the Pawns before striking.
moves.5... fxe5: Lulled into a false sense of security, Elzie completes the exchange.
moves.6. Qh5+: Ouch. Now it's a matter of how Elzie wants to lose.
moves.6... Ke7: The answer is quickly. 6...P-N3 7 QxKP ch folloed by 8 QxR would be how to lose slowly.
moves.7. Qf7+ Kd6 8. Nb5+: The King-hunt is on in earnest.
moves.8... Kc5 9. b4+ Kxb4 10. Rb1+: Adding a 4th piece to the hunt.
moves.12... Ka5 13. Qa4#: An effective, if not elegant, finish.
